background_dashed.customLabel: In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of MEMANT on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In NA participants, there is no difference between MEMANT and controls on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 1 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of MEMANT on Adverse events. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In NA participants, there is no difference between MEMANT and controls on Adverse events. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 1 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In NA participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of controls on Adverse events. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 1 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In NA participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of MEMANT on Anxiety. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 1 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In NA participants, there is no difference between MEMANT and controls on Anxiety. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 1 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
